resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.

fields.summary: Cluster metrics have wrong Total Memory when there is reserved memory on CS

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description: "Memory Total" is currently a sum of availableMB, allocatedMB, and reservedMB.  Including reservedMB in this sum can make the total exceed the capacity of the cluster.
fields.summary: In scheduler UI, including reserved memory in "Memory Total" can make it exceed cluster capacity.
In scheduler UI, including used memory in "Memory Total" seems to be inaccurate

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

comments.body: Sandy, I am not sure about this one. I would expect memory total to captured to total amount of memory in the cluster, and so be more or less a constant (not fluctuation due to reservations). I am not 100% sure, but I think that for the CapacityScheduler reservations count against availableMB, so it works fine as-is. Am I missing something?

Agreed that memory total should be the total amount of memory in the cluster.  In the fair scheduler, and I'm pretty sure the capacity scheduler as well, a reservation is a promise that the next time resources on a certain node free up, they will go to a particular application.  The purpose of these is to prevent larger container requests from starving.  So it doesn't really make sense to subtract these from availableMB, because they overlap with allocatedMB.

I haven't seen this problem happening with the CapacityScheduler (but I was not looking for it, so I might just have missed it).
In the CapacityScheduler reservation count against your capacity, but you might be right that they are not counted in the metrics.

Note this broke the UI, at least for the capacity scheduler.

It now displays total that is lacking the reserved.   Perhaps this is a difference in how fair scheduler and capacity scheduler keep track of allocated vs reservations.
